    Basic Routing

    Vue has an official library for routing web pages. To install this library: 

              
    
npm install vue-router@4

    OR

    You can also install the router when creating a new project using the Vue CLI, which is covered in the Getting Started section.

    There are two things you need to do so Vue Router will work in your project. Keep in mind, we are creating this in the context of a bundled project with webpack but should share the exact same concepts for non-bundled websites.

    Create the Router

    This is a two part process. To create the router we need to have routes established because the router will accept this part of an object parameter. 

              
    
import { createRouter, createWebHistory } from “vue-router”;

const routes = [
    {
        path:  ‘/’,
        name: ‘home’,
        component: () ⇒ import(’@views/HomeView.vue’)
    },
    {
        path: ‘/documentation’,
        name: ‘documentation’,
        component: () ⇒ import(’@views/DocumentationView.vue’)
    },
];

    In both routes we create the url path, a name for the route, and connect it to a component. In this case, we connect it Vue’s “view” pages.

    The first route points to home if the path is only a “/”. If the url follows a normal pattern: “https://www.WebsiteName.com/”, then our router will insert the page into the DOM without reloading.

    Now we need to create the router: 

              
    
const router = createRouter({
    history: createWebHistory(),
    routes
})

    Step 2: Instantiate the Router in Your App

    Now that we have our route and router declared, we can instantiate it into our application. We call the “.use” property after we create the app and then mount the app to the DOM. Doing all the normal things to create an app and just adding “.use” as a wrapper of sorts. 

              
    
import {  CreateApp } from ‘vue’;
import App from ‘./App.vue’;
import router from ‘./router’;

createApp(App).use(router).mount(’#app’);

    Now we are ready to use the router!

    Declare Routes in a Component <RouterView>

    In the parent component of your application we need to show where to inject the components (App.vue): 

              
    
<template>
    <div>
        <RouterView>  <RouterView />
    </div>
</template>

<script>
    export default {
        name: "PageOrComponentName",
    }
</script>

    In the template, we add <RouterView> where our components will be routed to within the page. Now this solves the problem of simple routing, what else can we do?

    Nesting Components

    1. Send Data to the Page/Component With a Route

    In this case, we need to change the routes: 

              
    
{
    path: '/documentation/:documentationPage',
    name: 'documentationPages',
    components: {
        default: () => import('@/views/DocumentationView.vue')
    }
},

    If the URL is “https://www.WebsiteName.com/documentation/getting-started”, the component that gets called will have access to a string that points to the value “getting-started”. To access this parameter in that component: 

              
    
data() {
    return {
        page: this.$route.params.documentationPage,
    }
}

    It’s kind of like passing props or parameters in a function, but instead of prop or function syntax, you pass a string via the URL slug.

    2. We can include a second component in the route:

    Route.js: 
              
    
{
    path: '/documentation/:documentationPage',
    name: 'documentationPages',
    components: {
        default: () => import('@/views/DocumentationView.vue'),
        component: () => import(@/components/NavBar.vue)
    }
},
    App.vue: 
              
    
<template>
    <div>
        <RouterView name="NavBar">  <RouterView />
        <RouterView>  <RouterView />
    </div>
</template>

<script>
    export default {
        name: "PageOrComponentName",
    }
</script>

    We add a component in the route and then we add another <RouterView> with a name to match up with the name of the component. This allows us to create dynamic pages and layouts by calling different components when needed.

    In short, this allows us to manage some logic in-page for displaying our website.

    For example, let’s say we have several pages of content for our documentation. We can use a dynamic route to send a string to the page to figure out which component to show. Let’s see it in action!

    Route: WebsiteName.com/documentation/getting-started

    DocumentationView.vue: 

              
    
<template>
    <div>
        <GettingStarted v-if="this.page === 'getting-started'" />
        <MakingAComponent v-if="this.page === 'basic-routing' " />
    </div>
</template>

<script>
    import GettingStarted from "@/components/documentation/1_GettingStarted"
    import MakingAComponent from "@/components/documentation/2_MakingAComponent"

    export default {
    name: 'App',
	data() {
		return {
			page: this.$route.params.documentationPage
		}
	}
}
</script>

    We import 2 components in the script: (1) GettingStarted and (2) MakingAComponent.

    The page has a route object that we access using this.$route and we dig into its properties .params and then find specifically the data we passed in .documentationPage (a string from the URL-slug).

    Then we do some v-if conditional rendering to decide which component renders to the page.

    This is a very simple way of doing things without having to dig further into the router’s capabilities to manage complex routing.

    The downside, despite this being simple way of handling basic routing and routing children components, is that you have routing logic in the router AND the documentation page. For a smaller website this might be okay, but for a larger project one may want to manage routing ALL in one place.

    3. Creating Children Components Using Routes

    Vue Router also gives us tools to render children without parent components. 

              
    
const routes = [
{
    path: '/documentation/:docTitle',
    component: () => import('@/views/DocumentationView.vue'),
    children: [
        {
            path: 'getting-started',
            component: () => import(@/components/1_GettingStarted.vue)
        },
        {
            path: 'basic-routing',
            component: () => import(@/components/2_MakingAComponent.vue)
        }
    ]
},
];

    If :docTitle matches a path, the router will then route to the corresponding child component.

    These should be enough tools to manage quite a bit of complexity for a developer’s routing needs. There will be further chapters on routing created that go in more depth.
